FIGURE.P: The last Scene of part the 2d. in the Christmas Tale.

DIV1.P: A NEW DRAMATIC ENTERTAINMENT, CALLED A Christmas Tale. IN FIVE PARTS. AS IT IS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE. Embellished with an Etching, by Mr. Loutherbourg.
LONDON: Printed for T. BECKET, in the Strand. MDCCLXXIV. [Price One Shilling and Six-pence.]

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: THE writer of the following Tale begs leave to make his acknow∣ledgements to the publick, for their very favourable reception of it: He hopes that the success attending this attempt, so well supported by the Scenery, Musick, and Performers, will excite superior talents to pro∣ductions of the same kind, more worthy of their approbation.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.STAGE: Music plays, and several persons enter with different kind of dishes.
After them Mr. PALMER, in the character of CHRISTMAS.

LG.L: GO on—prepare my bounty for my friends,
And see that mirth with all her crew attends:
Behold a personage well known to fame;
Once lov'd and honour'd—Christmas is my name!
My officers of state my taste display;
Cooks, scullions, pastry-cooks, prepare my way!
Holly, and ivy, round me honours spread,
And my retinue shew, I'm not ill-fed:
Minc'd pies by way of belt, my breast divide,
And a large carving knife, adorns my side;
'Tis no Fop's weapon, 'twill be often drawn;
This turban for my head is collar'd brawn!
Tho' old, and white my locks, my cheeks are cherry,
Warm'd by good fires, good cheer, I'm always merry:
With carrol, fiddle, dance, and pleasant tale,
Jest, gihe, prank, gambol, mummery and ale,
I, English hearts rejoic'd in days of yore;
For new strange modes, imported by the score,
You will not sure turn Christmas out of door!
Suppose yourselves, well seated by a fire,
(Stuck close, you seem more warm than you desire)
Old father Christmas now in all his glory,
Begs with kind hearts, you'll listen to his Story:
Clear well your minds from politicks and spleen,
Hear my Tale out—see all that's to be seen!
Take care, my children, that you well behave,
You, Sir, in blue, red cape—not quite so grave:
That critick there in black—so stern and thin,
Before you frown, pray let the tale begin—
You in the crimson capuchin, I fear you,
Why, Madam, at this time so cross appear you?
Excuse me pray—I did not see your husband near you.
Don't think, fair Ladies, I expect that you,
Should hear my tale—you've something else to do:
Nor will our beaux, old English fare encourage;
No foreign taste, could e'er digest plumb-porridge.
I have no sauce to quicken lifeless sinners,
My food is meant forTo the upper gallery. honest hearty grinners!
For you—you spirits with good stomachs bring;
O make the neighb'ring roof with rapture ring;
Open your mouths, pray swallow every thing!
Criticks beware, how you our pranks despise;
Hear well my tale, or you shan't touch my pies;
The proverb change—be merry, but not wise.

DIV1.HEAD: Dramatis Personae.

LIST.HEAD: GOOD and EVIL SPIRITS, in various Characters, by

DIV1.P: The SCENERY invented by Mr. DE LOUTHERBOURG.

SP.P: TYCHO, Tycho! where are you, Tycho? sure the fellow has taken me at my word, and gone to hang or drown himself—he threatened both—Lovers are great bullies, and swear a thousand things, they never intend to perform; if the poor woman shews any fear, the bullies rave the more, and she gives up at once that no∣blest privilege of the sex, making the wisest fools, and the stoutest miserable—I have a tongue to be sure that moves quick, and by out-running my wit sometimes, may encourage young coxcombs to hope too much; but then my heart all the while, poor thing! knows nothing of the matter, and feels no more, than my shoe-knots.

LG.L: Yet my heart in my bosom lies still;
But the miller's asleep in his mill.
Yet my heart in my bosom lies still;
But the miller's asleep in his mill.
But my heart is awake in my breast;
But the linnet's awake in his nest.

SP.P: Where can this Tycho have hid himself? I'm sure he went this way—stay, is not that my gentleman creeping along the side of the canal? It is either he, my other lover, Faladal, or the monkey in his new livery; I must give him a little more hope, or we shall have no more sport with him.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO
SP.P:
There's a hard-hearted she-devil for you!—do I look like a monkey in a new livery? I don't know how love may have alter'd me, but I know a few weeks ago, that I had the best face in this island, or my glass is a deceiver of youth. If I had not so much tenderness in my com∣position,
I would play the devil among these petticoats— But here she comes again, and I can't say boo! to her for the life of me.
It was the monkey, and a very pretty fellow he is, now he is well dressed.
La! what's that?—did not I hear somebody sigh? It must be my lover Tycho!—where are you, Tycho?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.STAGE: (In the tree, and out of sight.)
SP.P: Here am I!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Where?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Here.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Where, I say? Pray shew your sweet face.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Here it is. (peeping out.) When you lose this, you wont get a better.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Not 'till I buy a gingerbread one—What are you doing there?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I was going to hang myself for love; but, having left the cord behind me, I fell asleep 'till you waken'd me—Pray lend me your garters, for I will not live, that I am resolv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Come down, and I'll lend you any thing.—What can I possibly do with this strange animal.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Here am I!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: What is it you want?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Death or you.—I must have one of you.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Have not I told you often, and I will now repeat it, that I can't leave Camilla; let but Floridor, your friend, get the consent of Camilla, my friend, then I Robinette, her friend, take you Tycho, his friend.—What would the fellow have?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Your friend, and my friend, and his friend, and her friend: then all are friends.—Isn't it so?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: To be sure—Now go about your business.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: O bless me! now I am come to myself, I must send Floridor immediately to his father, upon special matters▪ I thought to make away with myself, and quite forgot it.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Floridor is as violent in love, as you are melancholly: You must both mend your manners, or Camilla and I shall look out for others—No more melancholy, Tycho, if you love, and would win me.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Am I too melancholy for you?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Too melancholly! your face seems preparing for a funeral, instead of looking out for a wedding: I hate me∣lancholy, and all melancholy people: A cloudy face betokens a cloudy heart, and I will have neither: Never will I sail to the port of matrimony but with a smiling sea, and a clear sky—that's the way to make a good voyage of it.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: And so it is, faith; he! he! he!—My face will be∣come smiles, as well as a great deal of thinking: I have study'd myself fnto melancholy, but I'll burn my books, and be as merry as you please to make me. He! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Now you dance about my heart, and will certainly run away with it.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: He! he! he!—But where's Faladel, Robinette?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Perhaps sleeping in some tree for love of me, as you did.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: If he would do the other thing for you, I should be very happy.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Melancholy and jealous too!—I declare off—Fye for shame! a man, a young man, of person, parts, address, and coversation, to be jealous of an old simpering, swag∣gering, rhiming gentleman usher, who is as dry as a mum∣my, and talks of love; has no strength, and talks of fighting giants; has no wit, and thinks to gain me! O, Fye, for shame!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: It is, indeed, both a sin and a shame—I'll know my∣self better, and be afraid of nobody but you, Robinette: I would say more, but it is time for me to laugh, he! he! he! is it not?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Now you shew yourself to advantage—But, look at the lovers there! they have had a fresh quarrel, I suppose; go and end it; and take the hot fool home to his father to cool him.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I'll be melancholy no more—to please you, Robinette, I will dance when I am sad; be pert and merry, tho' I have nothing to say, like other young gentlemen—I'll be quite in the mode, more of the monkey, and less of the man.—Tol, lol, lol.—Will that do? bye Robinette. Tol, lol, lol.—Heigho!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: I do like this fellow a little, though I plague him so— and perhaps I plague him because I like him;—he's a strange creature, and yet I like him—I'm a strange crea∣ture too, and he likes me—he has a hundred faults— hold, hold, Signora Robinetta,—have not you a little fault or two in the corner of your heart, if your neighbours could come at them?—O woman, woman! what an agreeable, whimsical, fanciful coy, coquettish, quick-sighted, no-sighted, angelical, devillish, jumble of agreeable matter art thou?

LG.L: As swift as thought we breed 'em:
No whims will starve in woman's mind,
Who the shifting clouds can bind?
Quick of car, and sharp of eye,
Others faults we hear and spy,
We are both deaf and blind.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: I cannot bear your jealousy.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: My jealousy would have merit with you, if you lov'd as I did—but I have done, madam, and have nothing more to say.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Then go to your father, who has something to say to you.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: I'll follow you, Tycho.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: What do you stay for, if you have no more to say?

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: I will but say three words, and then I'll come.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: If you have three words, the lady will have three thou∣sand; which, at about two hundred and fifty words a minute, will just take up—I know my time, and will be with you again.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Pray go to your father, I have told you my mind, Flo∣ridor, why will you press me to change it? Don't let an ill-opinion of your sex mislead you, and injure me!—I am resolv'd.—You have my heart, I confess it—'tis ungene∣rous to urge me farther, when you know my greatest dis∣tress is to refuse you any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: My suspicions, Camilla, are the strongest proofs of my passion.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Can you suspect me of such falsehood, as to pretend a passion for you, and secretly indulge one for another.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Nigromant, though a wicked, is a powerful magician, and his frequent visits might alarm a heart less sensible than mine.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: My pride will not let me answer an accusation that re∣flects the greatest dishonour, both upon you and myself.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: How can you suffer me to be tortur'd with jealousy, when you might—

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Stop, Floridor! when I might—what? Scorn a father's commands, given me with his last breath and blessing!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: With his last breath, and blessing!

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Upon his death bed he enjoin'd me, with tears in his eyes, not to give my hand but to him who could give me proofs of what this inchanted laurel would unfold.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: And what are they?—I conjure you tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: See, and behold!
SP.STAGE: [The laurel unfolds and discovers the words Valor, Constancy, and Honour, in letters of gold.
SP.P: You have prov'd your Love to me, by its unfolding at your request—Now read what is more expected from you.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Valor, Constancy, and Honour! Can the son of Bonoro, and your lover, be suspected?

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: I must not hear you, Floridor: Can you love me, and refuse me these proofs?—Marriage, my father added, was too great a stake to venture upon common security: If your passion is a true one, you'll convince me by your obedience; if it is a common one, I am too proud to ac∣cept it, and too grateful to disobey my father.

LG.L: Sighs and vows will fan the fire;
Sighs and vows may traitors prove,

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: You shall have the proofs from me you desire, and in return, I will exact but one from you.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: If in my power, you shall command it.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Never see that curs'd magician, Nigromant, more.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
FLORIDOR.
SP.P: You have Spells to protect us.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: You have Valour to protect us;—it is you Floridor must deliver me from him; valor, constancy, and honour, may subdue all evil spirits, and it is by them alone, you can only reach the summit of your wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Then I will prepare for the trial.

LG.L: 'Tis Beauty commands me, my heart must obey;
'Tis Honour that calls me, and Fame leads the way!
From nhe soft silken fetters of Pleasure I fly,
With my love I must live, or with honour, will die.
Bring the sword, shield, and lance,
My name shall be famous in story;
And love is my passion and glory!

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Stay Floridor! I have something yet to do.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: What can this mean?—What now trial for a heart, so devoted to the object of its passion, that every trifling circumstance hurries the spirits to it, as if alarmed by ap∣proaching danger!

DIV2.STAGE: Re-enter CAMILLA, (with a wreath of flowers.)

LG.L: O take this wreath my hand has wove,
The pledge and emblem of my love;
These flow'rs will keep their brightest hue,
Whilst you are constant, kind, and true.
But should you, false to love and me,
Wish from my fondness to be free,
Foreboding that my fate is nigh,
Each grateful flow'r will droop and die!

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE I. Bonoro's Cell, with Prisons round it.

SP.SPEAKER: CHORUS of EVIL SPIRITS, from the Prisons.

LG.L: With folded hands and lifted eyes

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: What can be the meaning my son is not yet arrived? Love is his master now, and his father must wait, 'till su∣perior commands are obey'd. Tycho!— Tycho!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Here am I!

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Where is my son Floridor?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Where I left him—at the old place.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: With Camilla?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: To be sure!

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Did you tell him I wanted him.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: What said he?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: That he would say but three words and follow me. I heard him say a hundred, and sing a thousand: Lovers are bad arithmeticians.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Why did not you return sooner?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I waited for him, to be sure.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Have a care, Tycho—I will sooner forgive your weak∣ness, than your falsehood—tell me the truth; Robinette detain'd you.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I was a little love bound, I must confess.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Confess the truth always, nor ever be asham'd of the most natural, if not the noblest passion.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I am half dead with it, I'm sure. (sighing.) But I must never be melancholy again, and that it is that makes me so merry: He! he! he!—Heigh-ho!

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Let no passion raise your mind beyond its proper bounds, I knew of your foolish intentions—Such actions are the effects either of vice, cowardice, or poor paltry, mistaken philosophy.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: You need not throw away your lessons upon me—I am in spirits now, and always a laughing. He! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: That may be as foolish the other way; silly minds have have no medium.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: There's no pleasing some folks; full, or fasting.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: I pity your weakness, and am a friend to your honest simplicity.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I wish you wou'd give me some love powder for Robinette.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: She is forward enough without it—If her blood rises above temperate, you may repent the experiment.—Here's my son—leave us.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: With all my heart—I'll go write to Robinette.
I wish you had made a little more haste with your three words.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: No excuses for your delay, son—Your mistress detain'd you, and your father ought to wait.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: I am asham'd of my neglect.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: I excuse it—I know the noble resolutions you have made, which have more than half perform'd my commands. Camilla is an honour to her sex; deserve her, son, by your virtues, and my blessing shall attend your union.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR,
SP.P: Thus let me shew my thanks, duty, gratitude and love.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Rise Son, and attend to me—fome uncommon act of valor is expected from you.—Before I obtain'd your mother's hand, I conquer'd, and imprison'd thefe evil spirits, (pointing to the Dens) who molested the world in various characters: You are now upon your trial—What can so strongly demand your valor, as the destruction at once of your rival Nigromant, and the leader of these evil spirits?

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Nothing—may I prove myself the son of such a father!

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Valour is best attended by faithfulness and simplicity; Tycho shall be your 'squire—I will myself with the pro∣per ceremony dip the shield and fword in the lake of va∣pours.—But these incantations will not do alone—Valor, Constancy, and Honour, must render all my charms effectual.

LG.L: Though strong your nerves to poise the spear,
Though swift as light'ning through the air,
The sword of death you wield;

L.HI: 'Tis from the heart, the pow'r must flow,
To conquer, and forgive the foe.

LG.L: Though edg'd by spells, and magic charms,

L.HI: 'Tis from the heart, the pow'r must flow,
To conquer, and forgive the foe.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: As I feel your lessons, 'tis the best earnest of my execu∣ting them—but Sir! Father! I find you are inform'd that I am enjoin'd by Camilla to give proofs—

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: I am—Her father the good Bianco was my friend; his pow'r now possess'd by his daughter▪ was a limitted one; he was oppressed at the end of his life by the superior arts of the wicked Nigromant, for refusing him her hand—New what object can at once so warmly bring forth the proofs required of you, as so formidable a rival, and detested a monster!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: My heart pants for the contest!

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: If you conquer, my son, you gain glory and Camilla; if you are vanquish'd—come to my arms— (Embraces him) I shall have that melancholy consolation that you gave the best proofs of your virtues.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Your words melt me, and exalt me above myself!

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: I must away to the lake with the sword and shield—

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Shall I attend you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: No, I must be alone—Now mark me, son; stay you here, and in my absence be a guardian of these evil spirits; this wand, should they be riotous, or endeavour to tear off the talismans from their dens, will defeat their projects—
To secure your wand, sleep must not close your eyes 'till my return—a drowsy watchman is the robber's best friend—evil spirits have power only over thoughtless, lazy minds:

LG.L: Tho' honour loudly strikes my ear,
The softer notes of love prevailing,
Swell with hope, or sink with fear!
Who for the goal of glory start,
Would ne'er forbid this trembling heart,
I go—my faith and truth to prove,
Valour ne'er was foe to love;
I will, I must obey the call,

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Tycho!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Here am I.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Approach, my 'Squire.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Your father has told me of my advancement, and if a man of honour may be said to know himself, I will venture to say, that you are not very unfortunate in a 'Squire.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: I am convinc'd of it—and the first duty I shall put you upon, is to guard these evil spirits in my absence—I shall return directly, but I must see Camilla again—

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: To speak three words more—

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: I have something to say to her, which unsaid would damp the glory of any action I might atchieve, and which when said, will lighten, and strengthen my heart for any adventure.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: The moment your father has pardon'd one fault, you commit another—you keep his good nature in fine exer∣cise.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: I will never again give him the least cause of complaint— I must speak with Camilla, and directly,

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I have three words too for Robinetta—

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Don't be a fool, but mind what I say to you.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: A Knight may plunge over head and ears, while the poor 'Squire must not wet his feet.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: No talking but mark me—should these evil spirits dare to be turbulent, this wand will controul them—one caution above all is not to sleep upon any pretence whatso∣ever; should the wand drop from your hand, we are un∣undone!—be wise, active, and vigilant!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P:
The young sinner preaches well—I am forbid talking, and sleeping, I wonder he did not add eating and drinking too! 'tis very hard that I may not take one look at Robi∣nette; I am flesh and blood as well as he—am as person∣able as he—as jealous as he—have as fine passions, and am as much belov'd as he—To divert my melancholy, I will shew myself fit for my office, (it is not every fool in office
can do that) and examine these culprits, sinners, and evil spirits—I will not get too near 'em thò' for fear of their laying a claw upon me— (he speaks loud, and with an affect∣ed air) Who are you in this lob's pound here?—

SP.SPEAKER: First SPIRIT.
SP.P: Save you, sweet Signior!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Well, well, none of your parlaver—answer my questi∣ons directly, and keep your paws in your den.— (raps his knuckles) What are you?

SP.SPEAKER: JESUIT.
SP.P: I am a Jesuit.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: The devil you are!—and how came you here?

SP.SPEAKER: JESUIT.
SP.P: Having some cardinal virtues, and making larger strides then they said became me, they have laid me by the heels, and it is impossible for me to do any good here.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: No, nor any where else—so draw in your beak, cormo∣rant—And who are you with your sharp looks and your claws?

SP.SPEAKER: ATTORNEY.
SP.P: I am an Attorney, at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Not at mine, I beg of you—are you in for your virtues too?

SP.SPEAKER: ATTORNEY.
SP.P: A little mistake in practice only.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Then for fear of more mistakes, you shall stay where you are, Mr. Attorney.

SP.SPEAKER: POET.
SP.P: Signior Tycho!—I beg your ears a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: What have you lost your own?

SP.SPEAKER: POET.
SP.P: I am a poetical spirit, and here's a satire upon your neighbours, and a panegrick upon yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I'll touch nothing that belongs to you—I love my neighbours, and I hate abuse—so keep in your fingers, (strikes them). But who are you that swell and look so big?

SP.SPEAKER: STATESMAN.
SP.P: I am a political spirit, I had a soul of fire, that over∣leap'd all laws and considerations—I was a statesman!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: It was time to cool you a little, and spoil your leaping, by keeping your soul under lock and key—Who are you, friend?—and what are those rattles in your hand?

SP.SPEAKER: GAMESTER.
SP.P: A box and dice to divert us in our retirement.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Gamesters, I suppose—pray, gentlemen, what brought you here?

SP.SPEAKER: GAMESTER.
SP.P: We lost good fortunes, by keeping bad company, and to retrieve a little—

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Became bad company yourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: GAMESTER.
SP.P: We did take an advantage, I must confess.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: So they took an advantage of you, and put you where you are—I wish all your family was with you, brothers, sisters, and all!

SP.SPEAKER: ACTRESS.
SP.P: Turn your eyes this way, beautiful Sir, and look upon me with an eye of pity.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: O, the females have found me out at last! What are you, a hen Jesuit?

SP.SPEAKER: ACTRESS.
SP.P: I was an actress some months ago.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: An actress! what spirit's that?

SP.SPEAKER: ACTRESS.
SP.P: A spirit to entertain the public, but quitting that for private practice—

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: As you like private practcie, I wish you joy of your situation.

SP.SPEAKER: ACTRESS.
SP.P: If you wou'd permit me to come forth, and approach you, I would amuse you with my history.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Many thanks, fair lady; but as I know nothing of acting, we are both much better as we are.—Pray who are you, licking your lips, and with your mouth open?

SP.SPEAKER: GLUTTON.
SP.P: I am a luxurious spirit; I lov'd eating and drinking a little too much.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: O, a city spirit! I hope, friend, there is no great sin in a little eating and drinking?

SP.SPEAKER: GLUTTON.
SP.P: If I was out, good Sir, I would place such savoury dainty dishes before you!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, Sirrah; no bribery and corruption! He sets my mouth a watering already—this fellow shall be my cook, if I should ever get a good government.

SP.SPEAKER: WOMAN of QUALITY.
SP.P: Turn to me, Signior; I have a right to be heard first.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Then don't lose your right, I beg you—Who are you, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: WOMAN of QUALITY.
SP.P: A spirit of quality!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: And what are you in there for, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: WOMAN of QUALITY.
SP.P: For being a woman of quality.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: A woman of bad qualities you mean—Eye upon you! who ever heard of a bad woman of quality? this is scan∣dalum magnatum horrendissimum! You are a foul weed, and ought to be pluck'd out from the fair garden of nobility! I wish Robinetta had heard me say that.
SP.STAGE: [A voice is heard accompanied with a guitar]
SP.P: What have you singers and musicians among you?

SP.SPEAKER: ACTRESS.
SP.P: O yes, and dancers, actors, authors, and managers too: We could entertain you, sweet Sir, if we were at liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: No, no, you'll sing better in your cage, my pretty birds: Come let me hear you: (He sits down.) Whistle away—This is almost more than flesh and blood can bear: Such sweet looking spirits sure could never hurt one. (aside.) Come, come, whistle away, my sweet canary birds.

LG.L: O hear me kind, and gentle swain,
Let love's sweet voice delight you;
The ear of youth, should drink each strain,
As love and valour warm your heart,
And faith and honour guard you;
From wounded breasts extract the dart,
Our tear-stain'd eyes, their wish disclose,
O wipe the dew from of the rose,
And place it in your bosom.

DIV2.STAGE: [As they are singing, Tycho by degrees falls asleep.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: This is melting indeed! Bravo! bravo! Softly my an∣gel; not so loud, I beseech you—Sweet Robinetta! encore! encore! sing again, or I'll—As love and valor, (sings in his sleep) and beauty's lips. Toll, lol, lal, lal!—Robinetta— obinetta—binetta—netta—etta—ta—a—

LG.L: We fly, we sink, and run,
Folly sleeps, and Vice keeps holiday!

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE, Camilla's magnificent Garden.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: WHY would you distress me thus, and doubly wound me by this rash action? Your father will be incens'd at your disobedience, and hate me as the cause of it; Tycho may be work'd upon by the evil spirits, and undo my heart forebodes too—.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Can your heart be mine, and conceive any doubts of me!

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Why should I imagine that I have charms powerful enough to fix you mine for ever—change of place may occasion change of sentiment, new objects may erase for∣mer impressions.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Indulge not these false alarms; thou art queen of my heart, and shalt reign there for ever, and alone.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: My fancy teems with a thousand apprehensions, all my senses are in disorder! I heard, or thought I heart strange noises in the air; even now my eyes are deceiv'd, or this garden, the trees, the flowers, the heav'ns change their colours to my sight, and seem to say something mysterious, which is not in my heart to expound.

DIV2.STAGE: [The objects in the garden vary their colours.]

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: These are the phantoms of love and fear.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: O, Floridor! you have taught me love, and love has taught me fear.

LG.L: Look round the earth, nor think it strange
To doubt of you, when all things change;
The branching tree, the blooming flower,
Their form, and hue, change every hour;
While all around such change I see,
Alas! my heart must fear for thee!
Blighted and chill'd by cruel frost,
Their vigour droops, their beauty's lost;
My cheek may fade by your disdain,
To change my heart, all pow'r is vain;
Look round the earth, the flow'r and tree
To nature's true as I to thee.
These two verses are omitted in the representation. Look up to heav'n—nor think it strange,
To doubt of you, when all things change,
Sun, moon, and stars, those forms so bright,
Are changing ever to the sight!
While, in the heav'ns, such change I see,
Alas! my heart must fear for thee.
Clouded or bright, the moon and sun,
Are constant to the course they run;
So gay, or sad, my heart as true,
Rises and sets, to love and you:
Look in the heav'ns, each star you see,
True to its orb, as I to thee.

DIV2.STAGE: [He stops short, and looks stedfastly upon Floridor, who starts confounded; while Camilla appears distress'd.]

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Well you may start and be confounded, son!

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: I am the cause of his disobedience—let me be punish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Rise, excellent woman! (raises her.) Your virtues are the best excuses for his disobedience, which will become its own punishment—his labours are trebled by it!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: My father!

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Tycho has been overcome by the evil spirits—they have broken their chains, and fled to your rival and enemy, Nigromant—mischief is abroad!

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Then I am wretched indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Doubt not of my valor, or my love;—Increase of dan∣ger makes me more worthy of Camilla.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Your spirit charms me, and disarms my anger—I have disenchanted from sleep, and forgiven the poor penitent 'Squire; his was an error of judgment; yours of passion; but it is past and forgot. Tycho waits for you, with your sword and shield, in the grove by the inchanted lake— Begone! remember the words of this divine oracle; may Valor, Constancy, and Honour guide you—let no pleasures entice you—no terrors daunt you—when once you see him, never lose sight of your foe; follow him where ever he leads you; the greatest dangers are only the rugged paths which will lead you to renown, in the arms of in∣nocence and beauty.

LG.L: May heav'n's blessing blend with mine!
To crown thy deeds at virtue's shrine,
Be love's best gift, Camilla, thine.
May ev'ry sigh that's heav'd by me,
And ev'ry wish that's breath'd for thee,
Be prosp'rous gales on fortune's sea.
O when my bark the tempest o'er,
With pilot love, shall gain this shore,
Of ev'ry blessing love's the source
Till love and justice guide its course,
And then it mounts to fame!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P:
So, so, all matters are made up again; and the con∣fusion, which my poor, simple, melancholy lover, Tycho, occasion'd, is all kindly settled by the benevolence of Bonoro—I could not help list'ning to his fine sayings,
not out of curiosity, but it really does one's heart good to hear a fine preacher of morality, and which is wonderful, see him practise it too. But the lovers, I see, (looking out.) are taking their last leave—the good man can scarce part them—their lips are glew'd together—they'll never be got asunder!—it makes both my eyes and my mouth water— I'll look at 'em no more.

LG.L: Thro' all our hearts philosophers have taught,
Warm'd in the veins, it kindles quick as thought,
Be warn'd, ye fair, and retire,
If a youth comes, with a grace and a song,
Then to your heart the fiery atoms throng
And set it in a blaze.
But should the youth come, with honor and truth,
His heart in a flame, let yours be the same,
From him we need not retire,
O then we may play with fire.

SP.P: I don't know what's the matter with me to day, I am full of mischief I believe—I am afraid these evil spirits that are got abroad again are a little busy with me—it can't be the loss of Tycho sure that affects me—I don't love him so well as that neither—no matter what it is—why don't my loving cousin come back?—O this love! this love! she can't leave her dying swain.—Why should not I go after mine too? tho' I am not dying for him, he is for me—I'll go towards Bonoro's cell, I'm resolv'd—as I have less pas∣sion, I shall appear more generous by looking after my lover in his present situation.—I never knew 'till this moment that I was half so good a creature as I really am.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE, the Outside of BONORO's Cell.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Farewel, O farewel! my Floridor! Thou seest, but can'st not hear with what reluctance I am separated from thee!—He too with unwilling steps moves slow along, and turns his head this way, to shew that duty, and inclination, cannot yet be reconcil'd—now he stands still, and with his eyes, and one hand rais'd to Heaven, pressing his bo∣som with the other, he seems to swear eternal love!—I will ratify that vow, and make it mutual—now he seems dis∣tress'd, and hurries down the hill, and now he's gone!—and now—I'm wretched!—heigh ho!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Heigh ho! why he'll come again, cousin, depend upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: May I depend upon his coming again as he goes away, constant and faithful; his father warn'd him to let no plea∣sure entice him—is not that alarming?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: What is it your turn to be jealous?

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Can one love much, and not be jealous a little?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Can you be long in doubt, and have supernatural powers to assist you?—

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: The passions of Love counteracts all operations of ma∣gic, and levels us with the weakest—we can try gold, but we can't make it—it is conceal'd by nature from the wisest of us.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Make a trial of his affections then, by assuming a form, if possible, handsomer than your own.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: That is not in my power, I can assume a form less agree∣able, if possible, than my own, and with that, and some other circumstance, I am now going upon the trial.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: I will attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: No, I shall dispense with your company for some time, I leave you mistress of my garden, and my castle; see whom you please, and do what you please; make yourself happy, while I perhaps am seeking to be miserable

LG.L: O how weak will power and reason,
Passion urg'd the youth to danger,
Passion is to peace a stranger,
Seek I must my bliss or bane.
So the feaver'd minds that languish,
Thus to end or ease their anguish,

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Poor creature!—I would not have her cares for all her magic, and her grandeur—mirth has got such possession of my heart, that I defy all the handsome fellows in the world to take more of it, than I please to give them. I have two lovers, which I keep as two Monkies to divert me; I make 'em play me a thousand tricks, can change the very nature of 'em—if they grow mischievous, I pu∣nish 'em—if all monkies were served so, there would be less impertinence in the world—but mum—one of 'em here—this is too old, and too lively, I must make hi melancholy or turn him off.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Signora Robinette—I have follow'd you to say half a dozen kind words to you, and vanish; he! he! he!—by my faith and wand, I will not encroach upon you!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: By my faith and fardingale, you may vanish before you have said the kind words to me if you please! he! he! he! [mimicks him] well what do you follow me for?—

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: I could not help it—I knew where you was going, I followed you, and the following little ode came along with me, and is at your service.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Upon my word that's very pretty and very moving.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Indeed and alack-a-day, I shall certainly die soon, if you don't cure me with kindness, he! he! he! I shall in∣deed for ever and for aye—he! he!—

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: What is your disorder, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Alack-a-day! I'm troubled with the Tycho—Signora Robinette, do you understand me? he! he! by my faith I am!—

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Jealousy I protest—and of poor Tycho—

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Poor or rich—I am troubled with the Tycho, and I must either take steel myself, or make my rival take it— do you understand me? he! he! he! (claps his hand upon his sword) it is a serious matter I do assure you—he! he! he! there must be blood shed—he! he! he! by my faith and wand, there must i

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: I wish you would make it a serious matter, and not be grinning so, to spoil one of the handsomest faces in the Island.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Alack-a-day! I can't help laughing for the life of me, I was born so—tho' I'm unhappy all the while to despera∣tion, he! he! he! by my faith and wand I am!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: By my faith too, my heart shall never be a prize for the best grinner; you must shew your love to me, by wear∣ing a face of desperation, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: What kind of face is that?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Thus—your eyes thus—looking about as it were thus —or thus—

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Looking about for what?—my sweet cruel queen of hearts! he! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: For a tree, or a canal to be sure, to put an end to your despair.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: To dangle, or float upon!—I understand you—he! he! he!—by my faith I'll hit your taste, or die for it— will this do? or this, or this—he! he! he!

LG.HEAD: This song is omitted since the first night. SONG.

SP.P: I'll stand by my song for ever and aye.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: You're at your grinning again.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Alack-a-day! and so I am—I can't stop it—my fea∣tures run away with me—but I'll go and practise a little by myself—and return again directly, quite a new crea∣ture—by my faith I will!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P:
Ha! ha! ha! if every woman before marriage, would but train up her lovers to her inclination, as she does her birds
or her dogs, we never should have an unhappy marriage; to be too much in love, and to give men their way, spoils every thing—But what have we here? my lover, Tycho, and prepar'd for battle!—like master, like man; he comes to take his last adieu—He seems very sad and thought∣ful; but he sees me, and brightens up into unnatural smiles—Ah, Signior Cavaleiro Tycho!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Here am I! as merry as my situation will permit me—I have leave to kiss your fair hand and away. Tho' I am made a 'Squire, I have had sad luck since I saw you, (look∣ing grave, but recollecting himself.) But it is all over, and I don't mind it now, he! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: If I had not taught you to laugh at misfortunes, your last adventure, with the evil spirits, would have broke your heart.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: There was the devil to do! I have not recover'd my fright yet, I am sure, tho' I put a good face upon it, he! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Sad work indeed! but how was it?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Two she devils throw'd me into a trance, and as I could not help myself in my sleep, they help'd themselves out of their prisons, and left me to pay the reckoning.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: And a long one it was.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: It was indeed! but our kind old gentleman, gave me a four look, a long speech, pity'd my weakness, and forgave me—'tis a good old soul!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Sad work indeed, Tycho!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: It was horrible, horrible, and most horrible! He! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: But how was it?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: You must know I love music vastly, tho' I don't sing a note—and two she angel-devils, sung me so out of my senses, that I fell fast asleep.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Ay, ay, your old disorder—But I am sorry you can't sing, your rival, Faladel, who was here just now, sings very prettily.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Yes, he may sing; but he can't write as I can—I have wrote a song upon you; and who knows but you may teach me to sing, as you have taught me to laugh, he! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: O pray let's hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Your eyes are grey, but no matter for that, poets may suppose any thing.
You have a fine set of teeth, and if you had not, I was resolv'd to give 'em to you—I don't love by halves.
Let my rival do that if he can—I wrote it, and set it myself.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: I don't doubt it—But, Tycho, I don't know if a bright nose, is any compliment.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Why not?—You must have something bright about you:—but I don't want for words—you may alter it to wond'rous right—or white—or light—or tight—a tight nose, is no bad thing as times go; he! he! he!—Here comes my rival; shall I hansel my maiden sword, and lay him dead at your feet?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: By no means—Kill him with jealousy!—See how me∣lancholy he is; he has lost all his spirit.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: And I have got it; he! he! he!—What a dismal piece of mortality it is: I am quite asham'd now that ever I wore such a face as his.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Now for a curious scene!

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: I hope I have conquer'd my foolish nature, Robinette internally, and externally for ever and aye. But there my rival, (seeing Tycho.) shall I sacrifice him to you beauty and my passion?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: O, by no means! draw your wit upon him; cut him up with that!

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: You command me. What a simple fellow it is, grin∣ning like an ideot, without ideas?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Did not I tell you so? A smirking face gives me the heart-burn.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: What a poor melancholy fool it is—he has done for himself I see. Look at old miserable, Robinette; he! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: What a figure from top to toe!—Attack him, Tycho.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Your servant, Signior Faladel.—I am sorry for your misfortune; he! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: What misfortune, pray Mr. Merry Andrew?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Attack his grinning, Faladel. (aside to Fal.) Attack his melancholy, Tycho.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I verily thought, Don Faladel, that you had put your face into mourning for some family misfortune; ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: How can I help being melancholy, when I see how contemptible your grinning has made you? what a su∣perlative happiness! I would laugh now if I durst.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: As you are both my friends, and one of you something more—

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: A great deal more, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: I thought so, poor soul!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Pray let me introduce you to know each other better—

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I have no objection; he! he! ho!

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: I can have none to your commands.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Take hands then—You must not be rivals, (for I can but love one of you) and therefore be friends.

DIV2.STAGE: [Each of 'em winks at Robinette, which she returns as they are taking hands.]

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: What a fool she makes of the poor man!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: How she shews Dismal of!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Thank you, gentlemen—I need not say which is my choice.

SP.SPEAKER: BOTH.
SP.P: No, no.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: It is too plain.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Half an eye may see it.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: I must, therefore, now take my leave; first of you, Signior Tycho—Distress'd damsels, imprison'd Knights, and various adventures attend you—Don't be jealous, Signior Faladel, if I conduct this redoubted and magnani∣mous 'Squire a little on his way.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Not in the least!—How she jeers him.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Come, Don Tycho, the sword is drawn, the lance is couch'd, and the Knight is impatient.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Donna Robinette, my sword is thine, my valor thine, my heart is thine, my blood is thine, and at my return, my body shall be thine—Signior Dismallo, farewel! I wish your body joy of its wooden head. He! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: By my saith and wand, if I had not been commanded to the contrary—I would have divided his body, and spoil'd his grinning—but she hates and detests him for it, as she adores me for the contrary.

LG.L: Once as merry as the lark
But now I'm grown a sober spark,
For Robinette will have it so,
And what she will shall be,
I therefore take to ho! ho! ho!
And turn off he! he! he!
Once as merry as the kid,
I frisk'd it o'er the ground,
But since I am to laugh forbid,
For Robinette will have it so,
And what she will shall be,
I therefore take to ho! ho! ho!
And turn off he! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Poor foolish fellow, he is gone—he'll be a breakfast for some giant—I begin to pity him.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Alack-a-day! he does not know his own weakness, and has such a contemptible figure that he is below your pity, by my faith he is.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: I like his spirit, of knight errantry—it becomes him.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Do you? I have a prodigious quantity of it myself, and by my faith and wand, say but a word and I will be among the dragons, monsters, giants, and hobgoblins to∣morrow morning.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Will not that be depriving Camilla of the most com∣plete gentleman-usher, that ever bore wand.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Alack-a-day! all titles and services shall be given up for that of being your most humble servant and obedient Knight for ever, and for aye!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: If you will go—I shall present you with a scarf— come on, Sir Faladel.

LG.L: In rain, and wind, and snow,

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE I. A dark Wood.

LG.L: My Sword and Shield are lost!
The gates are ever, ever clos'd!
Away with despair to the wind,
Crown'd with these flowers I'll take the field,
My foes with this charm I will face,
Love alone shall supqly the place,

SP.P:
What a series of distresses, since they broke their pri∣sons, have these evil spirits prepar'd for me! they have convey'd my sword and shield from Tycho, have by their mischievous arts, disturb'd and intoxicated his mind, and all my fair prospect of renown, and possession of the
highest earthly bliss with Camilla is vanish'd and gone!— what can I say to her—what can I plead to my fa∣ther?—

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Signior Don Floridor, the lost sheep is found!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Here comes again the unhappy intoxicated wretch— where are you, Tycho?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Here am I.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Heve you recover'd my sword and shield?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: No—but I have recover'd a better thing—hic—my understanding!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: I wish I could see a proof of it.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I wish you had found your's, and then you would not be in such a passion.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Tycho, collect yourself, and answer a few questions.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Do you have all your senses about you, or I shall be too hard for you.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Prith'ee, peace—in the first place, at what time did you perceive yourself disordered?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: As soon as I found that I had lost my senses.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: How came you to lose your senses?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: As other people do—by seeing a fine woman.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: What Robinette?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Much handsomer!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: What did she do?—answer quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Don't be in such a passion—thus it is—Don Tycho, says she (looking with such sweetness as I do now) I have long admir'd you, lov'd or ador'd you—I forget which.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: No matter which.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I must be—hic—exact—looking sweetly as I said be∣fore—she stretched out the whitest arm, with the taperest fingers—thus—here Don Tycho take this—whenever you find yourself distress'd in mind—taste it and be yourself again—she gave it me, sigh'd, wept much, and took to her heels—I had just parted with Robinette, who with tears in her eyes, gave me this scarf—I seeing the poor creature so tender hearted about me—I grew tender hearted a bout her—sound myself low spirited, very low spirited— tapp'd the elixir of life, and was enchanted as you saw me.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Drunk you mean—as I now see you.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: No, enchanted.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Enchanted!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Yes, I say enchanted—I speak plain sure, I know what drunkenness is well enough; here is the enchanted vial!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: It was an evil spirit that deluded you.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Good or evil spirit, it is gone.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: It was one of the evil spirits, your folly set at liberty, that met you, tempted, and over came you—and the con∣sequences have undone us.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I shall know the traitress again when I see her, but don't fret about your sword and shield—you shall have mine, and I'll stand by, if I can, and see fair play.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: I shall go distracted with my misfortunes!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Here is the evil spirit!—hold, hold, if it is, she is vastly alter'd since I saw her.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter CAMILLA, as an Old Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Hold your peace, you intoxicated fool, or you'll repent your presumption.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I am not intoxicated with your person, Madam Nose and Chin.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P:
Cease your ribaldry, Tycho—forgive his folly, he is not
himself, or he would not have given his tongue such li∣cence.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Young Knight, civility should always be rewarded— what is the matter with you? can I be of service?

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Impossible! impossible! my mind will burst with agony!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I know you have a charm for the tooth-ach, and a spell for the ague—but can you dischant, or unconjure my brains—that is, can you with witch elm, crooked pins, a dry toad, or any of your family receipts, make me as sen∣sible as I was before—

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Very easily—drink of the water of yonder brook, plen∣tifully, and rest yourself upon the bank 'till you are call'd for, and the vapours of your brain will disperse, and you'll be sober again.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: As I'm a little thirsty, and a little sleepy, I'll take your prescription; and if I was not already over head and ears in love, I would take you too—kind old lady, yours— harkee—If you are his friend too—give the Knight a little advice, and bid him take mine, if he would go thro' life as he ought to do.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA
SP.P: Vexation, young man, will never find your sword and shield.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Tormenting me will never cure my vexation—why will you torment me, when you can't assist me?

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Young Knight, you don't know what I might do with kind usage.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Unavailing pity, as it wounds our pride, doubles our distress.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Passion blinds you, and you can't see your friends.

LG.L: Draws wealth, from the meanest of flowers,
And be wise as the humble bee.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Pardon me, venerable lady—you have cool'd my heated imagination, and my folly is a convert to your wisdom.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: I will shew my wisdom, by asking before hand what re∣ward you will give me, to recover your sword and shield.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: You shall command my services, and every thing in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Shall I?

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: By my sword, and honour of Knighthood!

LG.HEAD: SOLEMN AIR.
LG.L: By my shield and my sword,
By the chaplet that circles my brow,
To perform it, 'fore heav'n I vow!

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Will you as a pledge of our compact, give me those trifling flowers that are ty'd round your head?

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Trifling flow'rs, and give them to you!—you should sooner take my head from my body, or tear my heart from my bosom, than have the smallest bud of my sweet Camilla's chaplet.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: O love's extravagance!—I may command every thing in your power, but what you dont chuse to part with.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Ask my life, and you shall have it—this wreath is dearer to me than my life.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Well, well, I'll take you at your word.

LG.L: " To perform it 'fore Heaven, you vow.

SP.P: Behold what charms there are, in a young hero's services!

DIV2.STAGE: [She waves her stick, the wood opens, and discovers his sword and shield, hung upon the stem of a tree.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR,
SP.P: How delightful to my eyes, are these instruments of my fame and glory!—Now task my service and my gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: I am not in haste for my reward—other cares demand your services—I shall call upon you in my turn.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: To whom am I bound in gratitude for ever?

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Grinnelda is my name.

LG.L: Remember the words that I say,
For tho' I have past my May,
I'm not not frozen up in December.
Remember the words that you say,
And tho' you are past your May,
Your heart is still warm in December.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE II. The outside of Bonoro's Cell.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: My heart is agitated and distress'd! the various accidents which have befallen my son, make me tremble for his youth and inexperience; I am unhappy and perplex'd in spite of supernatural pow'rs; the feelings of the father rise su∣perior to every thing—Radel, my spirit, Radel!

SP.SPEAKER: RADEL.
SP.P: Here my lord and master.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Fly to my son with a troop of my spirits that he may not be surrounded and overcome by the evil ones, in his conflict with Nigromant.

SP.SPEAKER: RADEL.
SP.P: With the pow'r and virtue you have given me, I fly to execute your commands.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.
SP.P: Be swist as my wishes!

LG.L: No pow'r can calm the storm to rest,
No magic charm the father's breast,
Which beats with doubts and fears:
No more for active scenes I burn,
My pow'r and strength to weakness turn,
I will not doubt,—thro' stormy skies,
My son shall break his way;
Shall cloudless o'er his errors rise,
And Fame shall hail the day!

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE III. A prospect of rocks.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Heaven bless her for it say I!—you have got your sword and shield, and I my senses—we are both beholden to her, and should both do our best to be grateful: She might certainly have had me, had not Robinette engag'd me before hand. But what strange, fine, tremendous, diabo∣lical, grand palace have we here?

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: This is the domain of Nigromant—Tycho, should the demons come upon you, remember they are but phantoms, and will be dispers'd by one gleam of your sword, as va∣pours before the sun: If free from guilt, you may defy, and despise them!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Then I am their man!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Here will I plant my laurels, or mix my ashes with the dust.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: And I as your 'Squire, wall take a slip of your laurels, or slip into the next world, as other rash 'Squires have done before me.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Should I fall, and you survive, Tycho, take this chap∣let to Camilla, tell her, that my love never yielded, tho' my body did.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: And if your unworthy 'Squire drops, and you survive, (which heav'n forbid) tell Robinette, that Tycho was true to the last—tell her—that—that—But as I hope I shall be able to carry the message myself, let us to business, and put our loves in our pockets, 'till we have done fighting.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Approach the castle gates, Tycho, and sound the horn of desiance—Call forth the black magician, the wicked Nigromant, to single combat.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: To single combat, you're right—your commands shall be obey'd.
SP.STAGE: [Tycho sounds the horn; it thunders, the rocks split and discover the castle of Nigromant, and the fiery lake.]
SP.P: I have wak'd his devilship! and blown all his castle about his ears!

SP.SPEAKER: NIGROMANT.
SP.P: Floridor, son of Bonoro, I come!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Nigromant, son of darkness and mischief, I attend thee!

SP.SPEAKER: NIGROMANT.
SP.P: Floridor, son of Bonoro, I abhor thy father's virtues! I hate thee, and thy race! I call to thee, and defy thee! and thou shall feel my vengeance.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I don't like the sound of his voice.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Come forth, thou foul son of darkness! I have ex∣perienced the mischievous hatred of thee, and thy crew— Come forth from thy lurking places, face me like an open foe, and I'll forgive thee!

SP.SPEAKER: NIGROMANT.
SP.P: Here I am!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: This must be the cock-devil of 'em all!

LG.HEAD: SONG.
LG.L: Stripling, traitor; victim of my rage!
Vain are your magic charms and spells,
Revenge shall soon her laurels steep,
Thy terrors, threats, and boasts are vain,
Let all thy fiends surround thee,
On the whirlwind if you ride,
Thro' all your spells I'll break,
And plunge into the fiery lake,

DIV2.STAGE: [It thunders, and Floridor plunges into the fiery lake.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: A good journey, good master—your feathers will be sing'd at least; and if I had follow'd him, I should have been ready roasted for the magician's table.
Here come the demons! but free from guilt, I defy, and despise 'em!
SP.STAGE: [During the dance, as often as the demons approach Tycho, he claps his hand to his sword, and cries out, I defy you, and despise you; when they vanish he assumes an important air.]
SP.P: I have done their business!—
SP.STAGE: (A rumbling noise is heard in the air.
SP.P: Here is more work for me!—What have we hear, a feather'd monster?

DIV2.STAGE: Enter FALADEL, as a large Owl.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Evil spirit approach me not—If you will fight as a gen∣tleman ought, and come with a sword by your side, I am your man—but I am no match for your beak and claws, therefore keep off!

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Hoo! hoo! hoo!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I don't understand you, Mr. Owl.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: I am no evil spirit, but your rival, Faladel.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Faladel!

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: By my faith and my wand I am.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Faladel! ha! ha! ha! and they have made an owl of you, ha! ha! ha! I knew what your melancholy would come to, ha! ha! ha! but how came you so alter'd for the better?

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: I went a Knight-erranting, by the command of Robi∣nette, and the evil spirits belonging to this castle would not fight me, but, alack-a-day, chang'd me into this shape, to divert the ladies of the Seraglio, for ever and for aye!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: And a very comical diverting devil you must be, ha! ha! ha! I would not have Robinette see you thus, she will like you ten times better than before—Such creatures as you in your human shapes, (if they may be call'd so) are neither fish, flesh, or fowl; but now you are something —you look wise at least, have a handsomer face, a finer shape, and a much better pair of legs, ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: What, you have not left off your grinning I see, tho' Robinette hates it so—

SP.SPEAKER: MESSENGER.
SP.P: Are you Don Tycho, 'Squire to the victorious and magnanimous Floridor, son of Bonoro?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: And is he victorious?

SP.SPEAKER: MESSENGER.
SP.P: He has conquer'd and bound Nigromant, and by the assistance of his father's good spirits, all the evil ones are in chains.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Hoo! hoo! hoo!

SP.SPEAKER: MESSENGER.
SP.P: The conqueror has call'd for his 'Squire to attend his triumphal entry into the palace and seraglio!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: My heart is with him already, and the rest of my body shall follow as soon as my legs will permit it.

SP.SPEAKER: MESSENGER.
SP.P: I fly to let him know it.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Hoo! hoo! hoo!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: What makes you so merry?

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: One touch of the sword, that has vanquish'd Nigro∣mant will restore me—be a generous rival, and present me to him.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Upon my soul you had better take my advice and stay as you are—but if you will be restor'd again from your being something to your former nothingness, I will present you to him; give me a tip of your wing, and I'll hand you to your restoration—come along.

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: Hoo! hoo! hoo!

DIV2.STAGE: [He claps his wings with joy, and Tycho leads him off.]

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE IV. The Castle Gates.
DIV2.STAGE: The triumphal entry of FLORIDOR, To martial musick, With NIGROMANT and EVIL SPIRITS in chains. Then enter TYCHO, attended with the female Evil Spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Come along—come along—you are once more in my clutches, and I'll take care that you shall never catch me napping again.

SP.SPEAKER: Second WOMAN.
SP.P: Magnanimous don Tycho!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: O you couple of she devils—with your sweet lullabys —it was your string-tickling, and quavering, that un∣did me!—none of your hypocritical side-looks at me (they offer to play) dare not to touch those deluding strings, that poison to the ears of honest men, or I shall forget your sex, and drag you at my chariot wheels—

SP.SPEAKER: BOTH.
SP.P: Have pity upon us, most gracious 'Squire!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I will not be gracious—I have no pity—and I will be a severe, tho' upright judge—foul as you are, you shall have a fair trial, and be assur'd (for all your ogling and smiling) that I shall find better employment for your fingers than tinkling men of virtue asleep, that hell may break loose, and the devils have a holiday.

SP.SPEAKER: Third WOMAN.
SP.P: I have a petition to deliver.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Justice is blind and can't read it—when I am a gover∣nor, all my judges shall be without eyes, ears, hands, or pockets; no eyes to read petitions, no ears to hear 'em, no hands to take bribes, and no pockets to hold them.— I am an upright judge myself who will not be brib'd, and what is still more wonderful, am not worth a doit: —silence ye fiends!

LG.L: Say not a word—I've said, and said, is done:
Stop all your tongues, and let the court go on.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE, I.
DIV2.STAGE: A grand Apartment in the SERAGLIO.
EUNUCHS enter singing the following CHORUS.

LG.L: TOUCH the thrilling notes of pleasure,
The sparkling eye, and speaking face,
The toil, and danger, valor proves,

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: What a fine refreshment this is after the hard labour of fighting and trying causes?

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Tycho!—has Faladel receiv'd the benefit he expected, from the touch of my sword?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: It was wonderfully efficacious! he moulted so fast, that tho' he made all the haste he could to his apartment, he left as many feathers in the way, as if he had been pluck'd for the spit—the moment he is pick'd clean from the owl, he will resume the monkey again, and appear before your honour, to pick a quarrel with me; the old bone of contention, Robinette.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: We shall cool his courage—bring before us the un∣happy beauties, who have been forc'd away, and confined for the tyrant's pleasures.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO,
SP.P: Open the female apartments, and let their treasures be pour'd down at the feet of the conqueror.—Those that belong to the 'Squire, I shall visit privately, and dispose off by private contract—

DIV2.STAGE: (The chorus is sung again, during which, many women of the Seraglio, enter veild, and at last Camilla (who is in chains) and Robinette: They throw up their veils.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR,
SP.P: Earth and heaven! Camilla!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Hell and the devil! Robinette!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: All my laurels are blasted!

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Mine are in a sad pickle too!

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P:
My life, my love, my Floridor! all my sorrows vanish
in these arms! [as she runs to Floridor, he turns away] What cold, and regardless of me?

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Can I see you here, in the Seraglio of Nigromant, and not have cause to lament, in the 'midst of my triumph?

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Can you see me here, and in chains, and not find cause for a greater triumph than that which you have gain'd! unjust and ungrateful Floridor!—we were seiz'd upon by the magician, convey'd here to be the slaves of his pleasure; but my heart was engag'd, my mind was free, I resisted his passion, scorn'd his pow'r, and I triumph'd in these chains!—unjust and ungrateful Floridor!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Then I have conquer'd, indeed!—and thus I sieze the brightest reward, that ever conquest was crown'd withal!
SP.STAGE: (after embracing her, he takes off her chains.)

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Where are your chains, Robinette?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: I left 'em behind me.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I believe they slip'd easily off—but did you resist too, Robinette?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: I won't satisfy you—don't think that I am like Camilla, to be suspected one moment, and hugg'd the next!—

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Only say to satisfy my honour, that you came here a∣gainst your will, and I'll pass over the consequences.

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Your honour!—I prefer one feather of my favorite owl, I have here, to your whole mind and body.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: O ho! Signiora Robinette, have I caught you? what, do you prefer that owl, Faladel, to me?

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: To all the world at present—I did like monkies some∣time ago—my mind is chang'd—I hate grinning and folly—I am for wisdom and gravity—and so sollow your inclinations, as I shall mine.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: And so I will; for my inclinations are to follow you— She shall either take me round the neck directly, or I'll wring her owl's neck off before her face—She has taught me to be merry, and I won't be made miserable again, if I can help it—I have not conquer'd the evil spirits for nothing.

LG.L: The storm shall beat my breast no more,
The vessel safe, the sreight on shore,
No more my bark shall tempt the sea,
Scap'd from the rock of Jealousy.
Bright are the flow'rs which form this wreath,
And fresh the odours which they breathe;
Thus ever shall our loves be free,
With roses and with myrtles crown'd,
The conqu'ror, Love, smiles all around,
And leads in chains grim Jealousy.

DIV2.STAGE: [At the end of the song a Messenger enters.]

SP.SPEAKER: MESSENGER.
SP.P: For the conqueror, Floridor!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: By my assistance you recover'd your sword and shield, by which you have conquer'd Nigromant, and are pos∣sess'd of his treasures:—You are now worthy of my love, and therefore I demand your's:

LG.L: To perform it, 'fore heav'n I vow.

SP.P: What a spiteful old hag?

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Whence comes that letter, Floridor, which distresses and confounds you so?—I beg to see it—what's the mat∣ter?—You alarm me!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Don't be alarm'd, indeed it is nothing!

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Then let me see this nothing—what, more confounded? O, Floridor! false, false, Floridor!

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: To convince you, how little I value the writer, and re∣gard the contents—thus I destroy at once her vanity and your apprehensions.
SP.STAGE: [He tears the letter; it thunders, and grows dark; flames of fire are seen thro' the Seraglio windows; all but Floridor quit the place shrieking.]
SP.P: Is heav'n and earth in league against me? what have I done, to provoke this war of elements?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: The devils are got lose again—O, Signior Floridor, what have we done? The palace is on fire, the ladies have lost their senses, and I have lost both the ladies and my senses, for I saw—

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: What, what?—where is Camilla?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I thought I saw her carried thro' the air by the kind old witch, who sober'd me, and recover'd your sword and shield—but away—see the flames are coming upon us! I am no Salamander as you are, and therefore I shall get into a colder climate.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: I will brave it all!
SP.STAGE: [The Seraglio breaks to pieces and discovers the whole palace in flames.]

LG.HEAD: SONG.
LG.L: Place me in the front of battle,
Tho' death in all her ghostly forms appear,
My heart that knows no crime can konw no fear.

DIV2.STAGE: [The flames and the ruins of the casile vanish away, and discover a fine moon-light seene.]

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: What can all this mean? by what offence unknown to me have I brought this complicated distress upon me?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: What a dreadful combustion is this!—Where my Knight is, I can't tell; and where I am, and how I got here, the fiends alone who brought me here can tell—

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Hark! did not I hear a voice—who's there?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I hear a voice too! I am afraid no friendly one; I ex∣pect every moment to feel feathers upon my skin, and a crooked beak instead of a nose.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Who is muttering there?—art thou a good or evil spirit?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I am neither at present—and how you Signior Floridor can speak with so clear a tone of voice in such place as this, and in your condition, puzzles my philosophy—

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: My conscience upbraids me with nothing, and why should I fear?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: My conscience is not quite asleep—but I hope my play∣ing at hide-and-seek with the seraglio girls a little, cannot be any great offence, after Robinette had discarded me—

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Joy to you, Floridor! joy to myself—now I have caught you near my own premisses, I shall not let you go till you have fulfill'd your engagements with me—

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Where is Camilla, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: I have her safe, and very safe—a pledge for your ful∣filling the conditions of our treaty.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: My sword is ready to obey your commands.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Pooh! pooh! I want no assistance of your sword, not I; I must have your love, young man, and in return you shall have my maiden affections, for they were never yet bestow'd upon any one.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: What can I do, or say to her, while my Camilla is in danger?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Tell her you'll have her—she can't live long, and then Camilla may be your's.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: What are you muttering to him?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I was only wishing him joy of his good fortune, of which he does not seem quite so sensible as he ought.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: His joy perhaps is so great, he wants words to express it.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: What will become of us?—pray if I may be so bold, what tomb is that?—your late husband's?

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: No, no, fool! I am yet a virgin:—that tomb is in∣tended to bury any ungrateful lover, that may chance to come in my way—do you see that house there?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I see that—house do you call it?—I have seen a hand∣somer pigstye.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Aye that house, and all its furniture are mine—go you there, and prepare for our approaching nuptials.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: She's mad!—I cant stand upright in the house, unless I put my head out of the chimney.

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Why don't you do as I order you.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I'll bring it here, if you please?

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: If you are insolent—I shall take another course with you—do as I bid you, or—

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: You'll make me—I am gone.

LG.L: Take my hand my heart is thine,
My hand and heart they are not mine,
May love and all its joys be thine!
Are these the promis'd joys of love?
These are the raptures call'd divine!
My hand and heart they are not mine,
May love for many, many years,
Without its doubts, its cares and fears,
Each moment of our life controul.
What anguish tears my tortur'd soul?
Let me, sweet youth, thy charms behold,
And in these arms thy beauties fold.
I cannot hold, I cannot hold!
No more can I, no more can I,
I blush for shame, O fye! O fye!
And so am I, and so am I.
Are these the promis'd joys of love?

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: Come along,—come along,—I must compel you to be happy—give me satisfaction, or you will repent it—

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Draw me, tear me to pieces with wild horses—my 'ast breath shall sigh Camilla—for I am her's—and her's alone—

DIV2.STAGE: [The stage grows light, and Camilla quitting at once the form of the old Woman, assumes her real character and dress.]

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: And I am Floridor's, and Floridor's alone!
Behold the reward of thy valor, constancy and honour! the fire has try'd, and prov'd the value of the metal—come to my arms, my hero!—

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: Was Grinnelda, Camilla!—wonderful heav'n! let me first return my thanks there, (kneels) for inspiring me with that valor, constancy and honour, that has borne me up against every trial, and completed my glory and happiness, in the arms of my Camilla!

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: I resign my pow'r, fortune, every thing to love, and be belov'd by thee.
But see your father, to perfect our uinon.

SP.SPEAKER: BONORO.

LG.L: Clouds that had gather'd o'er the day,
Now leave the heav'n's more bright,
Sinks to the shades of night.
Those evil sprights, that late rush'd forth,

SP.P: Am I asleep, or awake, or neither? or both?—it must be a dream—

SP.SPEAKER: CAMILLA.
SP.P: I forgot poor Tycho—have you prepar'd for the nup∣tials?

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: I had almost prepar'd for a long voyage in the air.—I was luckily out of the hut to survey it, when a wind took it up like a boy's kite, and it was soon out of sight —I wish the old hag had been in it.

SP.SPEAKER: FLORIDOR.
SP.P: I must not hear you say a word against Grinnelda, 'tis thro' her that I am in possession of Camilla—

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: Then heav'n bless her for it, say I—but I see I must be thro' somebody, to be in possession of Robinette—and now is the time—

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: By my saith and wand, there is my rival, and he that will not die for you, ought not to live, and so let the stoutest heart take you for ever, and for aye.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: You owl, you! come on, I will soon make you look more dismal than you are!

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: You monkey, you!—I will spoil your grinning, and sattle your features in a moment, by my knighthood, I will—

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P:
Valiant Dons, a word with both of you, before you fight for that which you can never obtain—be assur'd, what
ever liberties, I may have taken with your folly, that I can never give my heart to an owl.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: That's some comfort—he! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: ROBINETTE.
SP.P: Nor a monkey—

SP.SPEAKER: FALADEL.
SP.P: satisfied, for ever and for aye.

SP.SPEAKER: TYCHO.
SP.P: take your scarf again, (pulling it off) I won't stay to be laugh'd at—if your love-stomach for me returns —you know where to send for some plumb cake, this ho∣liday time, and so your servant.

DIV2.STAGE: [Bonoro waves his wand, the cloud ascends, and discovers a fine distant prospect of the sea, and a castle at a distance, with the sun rising.

LG.L: Ye once most wretched of mankind,
By tyrant pow'r and lust consin'd,
Come join our sports, and this way move.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter the different characters of the Seraglio, MEN and WOMEN, and join in A GRAND DANCE.
BONORO, FLORIDOR, CAMILLA, ROBINETTE, &c. &c. come forward.

LG.L: Hearts with hands, shall be united,
Hymen comes; his torch is lighted!
Love in my breast, no storm blowing,
Feels each tide is fuller growing,
Love in my breast, tho' a rover,
Will to day with joy run over!
Love in my breast knows no measure,
Swells and almost bursts with pleasure,
Here to share its boundless treasure.
Her virtue shou'd be crown'd with love,
And his with love and glory.
